elements.content: We have successfully constructed a tetrahedral Ti4L6 cage with calixarene-like coordination-active vertices. It further features high solubility and stability in H2O and DMF/H2O solution, affording an interesting stepwise assembly function with other metal ions. Through trapping of different amounts of Co or Ln ions, the Ti4L6 tetrahedra can be organized into various dimensional architectures, including a Ti4L6-Co3 cage, a Ti4L6-Ln2 cage, a Ti4L6-Ln2 chain, and a three-dimensional Ti4L6-Ln framework. An unusual mixed-valence phenomenon was observed in the Ti4L6 cage, whose Ti3+/4+ compositions were adequately identified by electron spin resonance and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy analyses. More remarkably, the calixarene-like oxygen vertices of the Ti4L6 cage can also be used for the recognition of C 3-symmetric dye molecules through N–H···O hydrogen bonding. Accordingly, driven by visible light, selective and efficient homogeneous photodecomposition of acid blue 93 and alkali blue 4B were successfully achieved. Therefore, this work not only represents a milestone in constructing symmetric Ti-based cages with interesting coordination assembly function but also provides a new method for preparing technologically important soluble photoactive cages.

elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Polyhedral coordination cages have attracted considerable attention in the past two decades because of their aesthetically appealing structures and wide applications in various fields. Currently, most of the research interest in this field has been devoted to the construction of discrete cages themselves. The further assembly of cages into advanced supramolecular materials is relatively less developed. Only a few cages have been organized into networks through labile coordination sites, interlocked molecules by mechanical bonds, and metallohydrogels using weak interactions. It still remains a challenge to find efficient methodologies for cage-based further assembly. Reasonably, if a cage could possess coordination function itself, we would easily assemble it with metal ions to form supramolecular architectures. The realization of such a proposal depends on the construction of coordination-active cages, which are still very rare to date.

elements.content: On the other hand, the preparation of cages mostly involves metal-directed self-assembly between metal ions and organic ligands. Thus, the geometric and electronic characteristics of the selected metal nodes greatly determine the structures and properties of the targeted supramolecular complexes. Compared with the intensively applied Pd, Pt, Fe, Zn, Co, and lanthanides, metal–organic cages based on earth-abundant Ti are still relatively few. As for tetrahedral Ti4L4 and Ti4L6 cages, to the best of our knowledge, only several examples were reported by Raymond. Considering the excellent photocatalytic performances of titanium-containing materials, the Ti-based cages would also have good potential for photoactive applications.
elements.clean_text: On the other hand, the preparation of cages mostly involves metal-directed self-assembly between metal ions and organic ligands. Thus, the geometric and electronic characteristics of the selected metal nodes greatly determine the structures and properties of the targeted supramolecular complexes. Compared with the intensively applied Pd, Pt, Fe, Zn, Co, and lanthanides, metal-organic cages based on earth-abundant Ti are still relatively few. As for tetrahedral Ti4L4 and Ti4L6 cages, to the best of our knowledge, only several examples were reported by Raymond. Considering the excellent photocatalytic performances of titanium-containing materials, the Ti-based cages would also have good potential for photoactive applications.

elements.content: On the basis of our former success with titanium–oxo clusters, we decided to investigate the assembly of symmetric polynuclear Ti cages (PTCs) and selected the cheap embonic acid (H4L) as a twofold-symmetric organic linker (). The naphthyl moieties can rotate freely about the central sp3 carbon atom to adopt the desired bend angle for the potential Ti4L6 tetrahedral cage construction. Meantime, this ligand contains abundant carboxylate and phenol groups to endow it with strong coordination affinity toward Ti ions. Moreover, as shown in , if the Ti ion is chelated by adjacent phenol and carboxylate oxygen, the η0η1-type carboxylate groups from three edge L’s may form a calixarene-like vertex. Then the four coordination-active vertices can further encapsulate other metal ions to acquire additional functionality or assemble the cages into advanced structures.
elements.clean_text: On the basis of our former success with titanium-oxo clusters, we decided to investigate the assembly of symmetric polynuclear Ti cages (PTCs) and selected the cheap embonic acid (H4L) as a twofold-symmetric organic linker (). The naphthyl moieties can rotate freely about the central sp3 carbon atom to adopt the desired bend angle for the potential Ti4L6 tetrahedral cage construction. Meantime, this ligand contains abundant carboxylate and phenol groups to endow it with strong coordination affinity toward Ti ions. Moreover, as shown in , if the Ti ion is chelated by adjacent phenol and carboxylate oxygen, the η0η1-type carboxylate groups from three edge L's may form a calixarene-like vertex. Then the four coordination-active vertices can further encapsulate other metal ions to acquire additional functionality or assemble the cages into advanced structures.

elements.clean_text: 1  Assembly of the Tetrahedral M4L6 Cage with Calixarene-like Coordination-Active Vertices for Potential Metal Ion Trapping

elements.content: Following the above structural design, Ti­(OiPr)4 or TiCl4 was solvothermally assembled with embonic acid in the presence of ethylenediamine (en), n-propanol, and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), giving rise to anionic tetrahedral Ti4L6 cages in orthorhombic (PTC-101) or cubic (PTC-102) supramolecular arrangements ( and and S4). The expected coordination-active vertices are found in this Ti4L6 tetrahedron. Moreover, electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (ESI-MS) analysis indicated that it is soluble and stable in H2O and DMF/H2O solution. Such unique characters allow the Ti4L6 cage to further trap Co or Ln ions to achieve advanced assemblies from zero- to three-dimensional (PTC-103 to -106). Similar Zr4L6 (PTC-101­(Zr) and PTC-102­(Zr)) and Hf4L6 (PTC-101­(Hf) and PTC-102­(Hf)) tetrahedra were also constructed, proving the universality of our method. Interestingly, electron spin resonance (ESR) spectroscopy and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) studies confirmed the existence of Ti3+ ions in the Ti4L6 cages of PTC-101 and PTC-102, making them rare mixed-valence Ti3+/4+ complexes. Moreover, the aqueous-soluble Ti4L6 cages can also act as visible-light-active homogeneous photocatalysts for dye decomposition. Moreover, such a photodecomposition process is not only efficient but also quite selective, which can be attributed to the molecular recognition ability of the Ti4L6 cage through its calixarene-like oxygen vertices.

All reagents were purchased commercially and used without further purification. All syntheses were carried out in 20 mL vials under autogenous pressure. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were carried out on a Vario Micro E III analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analyses were recorded on a Rigaku Dmax2500 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å) with a step size of 0.05°. Thermal stability studies were carried out on a NETZSCH STA-449C thermal analyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under a nitrogen atmosphere. ESI-MS was carried out on an Impact II UHR-TOF instrument (Bruker). UV–vis absorption spectra were measured on a PerkinElmer Lambda 950 UV–vis spectrophotometer. XPS analysis was performed on a Physical Electronics Quantum 2000 instrument equipped with a monochromatic Al Kα source (Kα = 1486.6 eV) at 300 W under ultrahigh vacuum. ESR spectra were recorded on a Bruker ER-420 spectrometer with a 100 kHz magnetic field in the X band at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

All reagents were purchased commercially and used without further purification. All syntheses were carried out in 20 mL vials under autogenous pressure. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were carried out on a Vario Micro E III analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analyses were recorded on a Rigaku Dmax2500 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å) with a step size of 0.05°. Thermal stability studies were carried out on a NETZSCH STA-449C thermal analyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under a nitrogen atmosphere. ESI-MS was carried out on an Impact II UHR-TOF instrument (Bruker). UV-vis absorption spectra were measured on a PerkinElmer Lambda 950 UV-vis spectrophotometer. XPS analysis was performed on a Physical Electronics Quantum 2000 instrument equipped with a monochromatic Al Kα source (Kα = 1486.6 eV) at 300 W under ultrahigh vacuum. ESR spectra were recorded on a Bruker ER-420 spectrometer with a 100 kHz magnetic field in the X band at room temperature.

elements.content: Ti­(OiPr)4 (160 μL, 0.5 mmol), H4L (155 mg, 0.4 mmol), and 2 drops of ethylenediamine (en) were added to 6 mL of n-propanol/DMF (3:1 v/v) and mixed at room temperature. The resultant solution was heated at 100 °C for 3 days. After the reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature, red crystals of PTC-101 were obtained. Yield: 78% based on H4L. Elemental analysis for C188H226N18O46Ti4, Calcd (%): C, 61.60; H, 6.21; N, 6.87. Found: C, 61.56; H, 6.27; N, 6.79.

elements.content:
These compounds were synthesized by substituting Eu­(NO3)3·6H2O with the corresponding Ln salts in the above synthetic procedure for PTC-106.

X-ray Crystallography

Crystallographic data for PTC-101 to PTC-106 were collected on a Supernova single-crystal diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromatized Cu Kα or Mo Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 or 0.71073 Å, respectively) at 273 K. Absorption corrections were applied using SADABS. The structures were solved by the direct method and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using SHELXTL. In these structures, some cations and free solvent molecules were highly disordered and could not be located. The diffuse electron densities resulting from these residual cations and solvent molecules were removed from the data set using the SQUEEZE routine of PLATON and refined further using the data generated. In addition, for structures PTC-102 to PTC-105, the crystals under investigation showed no significant intensity above 1.05 Å resolution. Because of the low diffraction intensity, some benzene rings of the L ligands could not be located in PTC-105. Crystal data and details of data collection and refinement of PTC-101 to PTC-106, including PTC-102­(Zr) and PTC-102­(Hf), are summarized in Table S1. CCDC 1552882–1552889 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre.

elements.content: Photodecomposition of the dyes acid blue 93 (AB-93), alkali blue 4B (AB-4B), methylene blue (MB), methyl orange (MO), and rhodamine B (RhB) by PTC-101 and PTC-106 was investigated under visible-light irradiation (LED-T8). Typically 20 mg of photocatalyst (PTC-101 or PTC-106) was added to 2.5 mL of H2O/DMF (4:1 v/v), and then 50 μL of dye aqueous solution (1.25 × 10–2 M) was added to the mixture in the dark for 5 min to achieve an adsorption–desorption equilibrium, followed by visible-light irradiation. The concentration of dye was determined at its maximum absorption wavelength using a UV–vis spectrophotometer.

Photocatalysis

Photodecomposition of the dyes acid blue 93 (AB-93), alkali blue 4B (AB-4B), methylene blue (MB), methyl orange (MO), and rhodamine B (RhB) by PTC-101 and PTC-106 was investigated under visible-light irradiation (LED-T8). Typically 20 mg of photocatalyst (PTC-101 or PTC-106) was added to 2.5 mL of H2O/DMF (4:1 v/v), and then 50 μL of dye aqueous solution (1.25 × 10-2 M) was added to the mixture in the dark for 5 min to achieve an adsorption-desorption equilibrium, followed by visible-light irradiation. The concentration of dye was determined at its maximum absorption wavelength using a UV-vis spectrophotometer.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that the Ti4L6 cage in PTC-101 and PTC-102 displays a tetrahedral geometry with the four Ti atoms situated at the vertices and the six L ligands defining the edges (). Each Ti center is chelated by three carboxyl–phenol groups from three different ligands, giving rise to a distorted octahedral coordination geometry. Another uncoordinated carboxyl oxygen atom is exposed outside. Thus, the three carboxyl groups from three different ligands around the same Ti atom form a calixarene-like arrangement filled with coordination-active oxygen sites. The ligands in the Ti4L6 cage are in the twisted forms, with an average intersection angle of 87.4° between the two naphthalene rings in PTC-101 (Figure S3). The Ti···Ti distances are in the range of 8.79 to 8.92 Å. The free spaces inside and between Ti4L6 cages are occupied by the disordered amine cations and solvent molecules. Interestingly, this Ti4L6 cage is a chiral one (Figure S2). The guest molecules significantly influence the cage resolution, with PTC-101 containing the ΔΔΔΔ-[Ti4L6] and ΛΛΛΛ-[Ti4L6] isomers in its achiral crystal structure. However, the crystallization of PTC-102 occurred with spontaneous resolution, leading to a chiral structure with simple ΔΔΔΔ-[Ti4L6] isomers.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Characterizations of the Ti4L6 Cages

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that the Ti4L6 cage in PTC-101 and PTC-102 displays a tetrahedral geometry with the four Ti atoms situated at the vertices and the six L ligands defining the edges (). Each Ti center is chelated by three carboxyl-phenol groups from three different ligands, giving rise to a distorted octahedral coordination geometry. Another uncoordinated carboxyl oxygen atom is exposed outside. Thus, the three carboxyl groups from three different ligands around the same Ti atom form a calixarene-like arrangement filled with coordination-active oxygen sites. The ligands in the Ti4L6 cage are in the twisted forms, with an average intersection angle of 87.4° between the two naphthalene rings in PTC-101 (Figure S3). The Ti⋅⋅⋅Ti distances are in the range of 8.79 to 8.92 Å. The free spaces inside and between Ti4L6 cages are occupied by the disordered amine cations and solvent molecules. Interestingly, this Ti4L6 cage is a chiral one (Figure S2). The guest molecules significantly influence the cage resolution, with PTC-101 containing the ΔΔΔΔ-[Ti4L6] and ΛΛΛΛ-[Ti4L6] isomers in its achiral crystal structure. However, the crystallization of PTC-102 occurred with spontaneous resolution, leading to a chiral structure with simple ΔΔΔΔ-[Ti4L6] isomers.

elements.content: As mentioned above, in the structure of the Ti4L6 cage there are four calixarene-like vertices filled by oxygen atoms, which should be active for coordination to metal ions. Also, from the viewpoint of charge balancing, the anionic nature of the Ti4L6 cage also makes it very easily combine with cationic metal ions. Therefore, this Ti4L6 should be an ideal candidate for the investigation of the stepwise assembly of metal–organic cages. Before this proposal was carried out, the solution behaviors of the Ti4L6 cage were studied. It was very interesting to find that the crystals of PTC-101 and PTC-102 can be readily dissolved in water (saturated at 2.5 g·L–1 at 80 °C), making these Ti4L6 tetrahedra rare examples of water-soluble cages (Figure S5). When DMF was further introduced as a cosolvent, the solubility of the Ti4L6 cages significantly increased (). Then ESI-MS spectra of the H2O and DMF/H2O solutions of PTC-101 were recorded (Figures S5 and ), confirming the high stability of the Ti4L6 cage after dissolution.

elements.content: On the basis of the coordination activity and solubility/stability of the Ti4L6 tetrahedron, its stepwise assembly with other metal ions was investigated. At the beginning, Co2+ ions were added to the DMF/H2O solution of PTC-101, which was heated at 80 °C for 3 days, forming red hexagonal-prism crystals of PTC-103. Structural analysis revealed that PTC-103 crystallizes in the trigonal crystal system with space group P3̅c1. As shown in a, each Ti4L6 cage catches three Co atoms by three formerly uncoordinated carboxyl oxygen atoms at one vertex of the tetrahedron. Each Co center is six-coordinated to form a distorted octahedral geometry. The three-dimensional (3D) packing superstructure of these Ti4L6-Co3 cages shows honeycomb-like channels with an effective window size of 15.5 Å along the c axis (b). Similar reactions using a DMF/H2O solution of PTC-102 as the cage source also produced PTC-103. In addition, an isostructural compound PTC-103­(Mn) could also be obtained by substituting Co2+ with Mn2+ in the synthetic procedure, as confirmed by the crystallographic unit cell index and PXRD pattern comparison (Figure S22).
elements.clean_text:
Coordination Assembly of the Ti4L6 Cages with Metal Ions

On the basis of the coordination activity and solubility/stability of the Ti4L6 tetrahedron, its stepwise assembly with other metal ions was investigated. At the beginning, Co2+ ions were added to the DMF/H2O solution of PTC-101, which was heated at 80 °C for 3 days, forming red hexagonal-prism crystals of PTC-103. Structural analysis revealed that PTC-103 crystallizes in the trigonal crystal system with space group P3̅c1. As shown in a, each Ti4L6 cage catches three Co atoms by three formerly uncoordinated carboxyl oxygen atoms at one vertex of the tetrahedron. Each Co center is six-coordinated to form a distorted octahedral geometry. The three-dimensional (3D) packing superstructure of these Ti4L6-Co3 cages shows honeycomb-like channels with an effective window size of 15.5 Å along the c axis (b). Similar reactions using a DMF/H2O solution of PTC-102 as the cage source also produced PTC-103. In addition, an isostructural compound PTC-103(Mn) could also be obtained by substituting Co2+ with Mn2+ in the synthetic procedure, as confirmed by the crystallographic unit cell index and PXRD pattern comparison (Figure S22).

elements.content: Molecular and packing structures of (a, b) PTC-103 and (c, d) PTC-104. (e) Z-shaped chain structure of PTC-105. (f) Molecular structure and (g) 3D framework topology of PTC-106.
elements.clean_text: 3  Molecular and packing structures of (a, b) PTC-103 and (c, d) PTC-104. (e) Z-shaped chain structure of PTC-105. (f) Molecular structure and (g) 3D framework topology of PTC-106.

elements.content: Encouraged by this result, more cage assembly procedures were studied using trivalent Ln3+ ions with higher coordination number instead of the above Co2+ ion. Interestingly, a series of Ti4L6-Ln compounds with different structural dimensionalities were readily synthesized by tuning the concentration of Ln3+ ions. The cage:Ln molar ratio of 1:6.8 gave the formation of PTC-104, which crystallizes in the monoclinic system with space group C2/c. As shown in c, each Ti4L6 cage captures two Eu atoms by two uncoordinated carboxyl oxygen atoms at two vertices of the tetrahedron, and each Eu atom is eight-coordinated. Such dispersed 0D Ti4L6-Eu2 cages further pack into a 3D superstructure with small channels along the c axis (d). When the cage:Ln molar ratio was increased to 1:3.8, red crystals of PTC-105 were obtained, in which each Ti4L6 cage catches three Tb atoms by three uncoordinated carboxyl oxygen atoms at three vertices of the tetrahedron (e and S8). There are two crystallographically independent Tb atoms (Tb1 and Tb2) in the asymmetric unit. It is worth noting that Tb1 atoms link adjacent cages to form Z-shaped infinite chains, which further pack into a 3D dense superstructure (Figure S9). Finally, when the cage:Ln molar ratio was further increased to 1:1.9, the 3D Ti4L6-Ln framework structure of PTC-106 was successfully built. It crystallizes in a symmetric cubic crystal system with space group P213. Although each Ti4L6 cage in PTC-106 also traps three lanthanide atoms, here each Eu atom connects three Ti4L6 cages to generate a 3D framework structure (f,g). From the viewpoint of topology, the framework of PTC-106 can be described as a 3-connected network by reducing both the Ti4L6 cages and Eu atom as nodes.

elements.content: Interestingly, such assemblies of Ti4L6 cages with Ln ions can be efficiently applied to almost the whole range of rare-earth elements. Through replacement of the used Eu or Tb ions during the synthesis of PTC-104, PTC-105, and PTC-106 with other lanthanides, three series of Ti4L6-Ln complexes can be readily prepared, and comparative PXRD analyses clearly confirmed that they are isostructural with PTC-104, PTC-105, and PTC-106 ( and S24). Moreover, DMF/H2O solutions of both PTC-101 and PTC-102 can be applied as the sources of Ti4L6 cages (Figure S28).

elements.content: To further verify the applicability and universality of our construction methodology for tetrahedral cages, other tetravalent metal ions like Zr4+ and Hf4+ instead of Ti4+ were introduced into the assembly system with embonic acid. As a result, isostructural Zr4L6 and Hf4L6 cages were obtained in the structures of PTC-101­(Zr) and PTC-101­(Hf) and PTC-102­(Zr) and PTC-102­(Hf), respectively. Although presenting structural similarity, the Ti-, Zr-, and Hf-based tetrahedra show different photophysical properties. All of the Ti complexes display red colors, while the Zr and Hf complexes are yellow (a and S11). UV–vis diffuse reflection spectral studies (Figure S12) confirmed that the Ti complexes have relatively lower band gaps around 2.0 eV, which should be mainly due to the penetration of the highest occupied phenol levels into the band gap of the Ti/O core. The calculated band gaps of the yellow Zr- and Hf-based compounds are ∼2.60 eV, which are obviously higher than those of the Ti analogues.
elements.clean_text:
Photo and Electronic Characteristics of the Ti4L6 Cages

To further verify the applicability and universality of our construction methodology for tetrahedral cages, other tetravalent metal ions like Zr4+ and Hf4+ instead of Ti4+ were introduced into the assembly system with embonic acid. As a result, isostructural Zr4L6 and Hf4L6 cages were obtained in the structures of PTC-101(Zr) and PTC-101(Hf) and PTC-102(Zr) and PTC-102(Hf), respectively. Although presenting structural similarity, the Ti-, Zr-, and Hf-based tetrahedra show different photophysical properties. All of the Ti complexes display red colors, while the Zr and Hf complexes are yellow (a and S11). UV-vis diffuse reflection spectral studies (Figure S12) confirmed that the Ti complexes have relatively lower band gaps around 2.0 eV, which should be mainly due to the penetration of the highest occupied phenol levels into the band gap of the Ti/O core. The calculated band gaps of the yellow Zr- and Hf-based compounds are ~2.60 eV, which are obviously higher than those of the Ti analogues.

elements.content: Electron spin resonance analysis was applied to study the electronic characteristics of the metal ions in the prepared cage compounds. It was interesting to find that the ESR spectrum of PTC-102 exhibits a strong signal at g = 1.985 that could be assigned to Ti3+ (b). The other signal at g = 2.038 should be attributed to O2 –, which is generated by reducing atmospheric O2 with the surface Ti3+ ions. The presence of Ti3+ in PTC-102 was further confirmed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy studies. As shown in c, the broad peaks indicate the multiple oxidation states of Ti ions. After deconvolution, the signals at 459.01 and 464.86 eV can be attributed to Ti4+ while the signals at 457.82 and 463.53 eV belong to Ti3+. The relative content of Ti3+ in PTC-102 was obtained by comparing the XPS peak areas and roughly estimated to be 25%, corresponding to one Ti3+ per Ti4L6 cage. However, the exact positions of Ti3+ ions could not be determined by crystallographic analysis, possibly because of the statistical distribution of Ti3+/4+ ions. Similar but much weaker ESR and XPS signals were also found in the spectra of PTC-101 (Figures S13 and S14). The production of these Ti3+ ions might be attributed to the applied organic amines, which have already proven to have reductive activities under solvothermal conditions. It is well-known that Ti3+-doped TiO2 shows significantly enhanced visible-light-driven photocatalytic performance. However, this kind of molecular mixed-valence Ti3+/4+ complex is still very rare. Thus, here we supply a new approach toward the important Ti3+/4+-O materials. In comparison, no signals could be detected in the ESR spectra of PTC-102­(Zr) and PTC-102­(Hf). XPS studies also confirmed the complete Zr4+ and Hf4+ compositions (Figures S15 and S16). Therefore, although Zr and Hf ions show similar cage assembly behaviors as Ti, their redox characters are quite different.

elements.content: Considering the excellent photocatalytic performances of Ti complexes, the photoactivities of the T4L6 cages were evaluated using dye photodecomposition as a model. On the basis of its high aqueous solubility, the solution of PTC-101 was used as a homogeneous photocatalyst, and because of its lower band gap, visible light (from an LED lamp for normal room lighting) was selected as the irradiation source. It was very interesting to find that the obtained T4L6 cages are active for the decomposition of acid blue 93 (AB-93), which can almost be completely decomposed within 10 min (). Moreover, the capacity of this homogeneous photocatalyst is also very high, as it can still retain its efficiency after continuous addition of four doses of AB-93 (Figure S30). However, it exhibits very poor photoactivities toward other dye molecules, such as methylene blue (MB), methyl orange (MO), and rhodamine B (RhB) ( and Figure S37). The intensities of the typical absorption peaks of these three dyes do not show obvious decreases even after 1 h.

Molecular-Recognition-Based Photoactivities of the Ti4L6 Cages

Considering the excellent photocatalytic performances of Ti complexes, the photoactivities of the T4L6 cages were evaluated using dye photodecomposition as a model. On the basis of its high aqueous solubility, the solution of PTC-101 was used as a homogeneous photocatalyst, and because of its lower band gap, visible light (from an LED lamp for normal room lighting) was selected as the irradiation source. It was very interesting to find that the obtained T4L6 cages are active for the decomposition of acid blue 93 (AB-93), which can almost be completely decomposed within 10 min (). Moreover, the capacity of this homogeneous photocatalyst is also very high, as it can still retain its efficiency after continuous addition of four doses of AB-93 (Figure S30). However, it exhibits very poor photoactivities toward other dye molecules, such as methylene blue (MB), methyl orange (MO), and rhodamine B (RhB) ( and Figure S37). The intensities of the typical absorption peaks of these three dyes do not show obvious decreases even after 1 h.

elements.content: We think the above photocatalytic selectivity of the T4L6 cage might be attributed its different supramolecular recognition ability toward these dye molecules. As shown in , from the geometric point of view, the calixarene-like oxygen vertices of the T4L6 cage match very well with the three −NH– groups in AB-93. Thus, the molecules of AB-93 can be drawn close to the T4L6 cages by three N–H···O hydrogen bonds in the solution, which can advance the energy or electron transfer between them and further promote the decomposition of AB-93. ESI-MS analysis of the products after AB-93 photodecomposition indicated that the bond breaks at the secondary amine position, which further confirms the important effect of the above N–H···O hydrogen bonding (Figure S38). As for MB, MO, and RhB, the lack of such geometry matching could not produce molecular recognition, resulting in poor photodecomposition activities (Figure S36).

As shown in , from the geometric point of view, the calixarene-like oxygen vertices of the T4L6 cage match very well with the three -NH- groups in AB-93. Thus, the molecules of AB-93 can be drawn close to the T4L6 cages by three N-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds in the solution, which can advance the energy or electron transfer between them and further promote the decomposition of AB-93. ESI-MS analysis of the products after AB-93 photodecomposition indicated that the bond breaks at the secondary amine position, which further confirms the important effect of the above N-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding (Figure S38). As for MB, MO, and RhB, the lack of such geometry matching could not produce molecular recognition, resulting in poor photodecomposition activities (Figure S36).

elements.content: In contrast, another dye molecule, alkali blue 4B (AB-4B) which has similar but less symmetric structural characteristics than AB-93 could also be decomposed by the T4L6 cage, but with lower efficiency (completed in 30 min) (Figures S33 and S35). Furthermore, the heterogeneous state of the T4L6 cage (PTC-106) shows significantly lower activities than the homogeneous cage (Figures S32 and S34). This might occur because the dye molecules can only be adsorbed into the surface of the solids and also because in the solid state it would be difficult for the T4L6 cages to move and rotate to recognize AB-93 and AB-4B through hydrogen bonding.

This might occur because the dye molecules can only be adsorbed into the surface of the solids and also because in the solid state it would be difficult for the T4L6 cages to move and rotate to recognize AB-93 and AB-4B through hydrogen bonding.

elements.content: A water-soluble and stable tetrahedral Ti4L6 cage with universal coordination assembly abilities and selective dye photodecomposition activities has been reported here. Because of its four calixarene-like active vertices, this Ti4L6 cage shows interesting stepwise assembly function with other metal ions. The Ti4L6-Co3 cage and different Ti4L6-Ln structures from simple cages to 1D chains and 3D frameworks were successfully constructed. Moreover, the calixarene-like oxygen vertices of the Ti4L6 cage have also been used for the recognition of dye molecules through N–H···O hydrogen bonding. As a result, the homogeneous Ti4L6 cage presents efficient and selective photodecomposition activities toward AB-93 and AB-4B. Therefore, our work not only provides an efficient methodology to build coordination-active cages for advanced supramolecular materials assembly but also opens a new way to produce photoactive cage materials with good activity and selectivity.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

A water-soluble and stable tetrahedral Ti4L6 cage with universal coordination assembly abilities and selective dye photodecomposition activities has been reported here. Because of its four calixarene-like active vertices, this Ti4L6 cage shows interesting stepwise assembly function with other metal ions. The Ti4L6-Co3 cage and different Ti4L6-Ln structures from simple cages to 1D chains and 3D frameworks were successfully constructed. Moreover, the calixarene-like oxygen vertices of the Ti4L6 cage have also been used for the recognition of dye molecules through N-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding. As a result, the homogeneous Ti4L6 cage presents efficient and selective photodecomposition activities toward AB-93 and AB-4B. Therefore, our work not only provides an efficient methodology to build coordination-active cages for advanced supramolecular materials assembly but also opens a new way to produce photoactive cage materials with good activity and selectivity.

Ti­(OiPr)4 (160 μL, 0.5 mmol), H4L (155 mg, 0.4 mmol), and 2 drops of ethylenediamine (en) were added to 6 mL of n-propanol/DMF (3:1 v/v) and mixed at room temperature. The resultant solution was heated at 100 °C for 3 days. After the reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature, red crystals of PTC-101 were obtained. Yield: 78% based on H4L. Elemental analysis for C188H226N18O46Ti4, Calcd (%): C, 61.60; H, 6.21; N, 6.87. Found: C, 61.56; H, 6.27; N, 6.79.

TiCl4 (90 μL, 0.4 mmol), H4L (120 mg, 0.3 mmol), and 2 drops of en were added to 6 mL of n-propanol/DMF (3:1 v/v) and mixed at room temperature. The resultant solution was heated at 100 °C for 2 days. After the reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature, red crystals of PTC-102 were obtained. Yield: 65% based on H4L. Elemental analysis for C191H235N14O47ClTi4, Calcd (%): C, 61.90; H, 5.92; N, 5.29. Found: C, 61.95; H, 5.89; N, 5.30.
